coredata.dc:title: Continuously adaptive data fusion and model relearning for particle filter tracking with multiple features
coredata.dc:publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2016 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
abstract.ce:para: This paper presents a new method for object tracking in a camera sensor with particle filters. The method enables multiple target and background models, arbitrarily spanning many features or imaging modalities, to be adaptively fused to provide optimal discriminating ability against changing backgrounds, which may present varying degrees of clutter and camouflage for different kinds of features at different times. Furthermore, we show how to continuously and robustly relearn all models for all feature modalities online during tracking and for targets whose appearance may be continually changing. Both the data fusion weightings and model relearning parameters are robustly adapted at each frame, by extracting contextual information to inform the saliency assessments of each part of each model. In addition, we propose a two-step estimation method for improving robustness, by preventing excessive drifting of particles during tracking past challenging, cluttered background scenes. We demonstrate the method by implementing a version of the tracker, which combines both shape and color models, and testing it on a publicly available benchmark data set. Results suggest that the proposed method outperforms a number of wellknown state-of-the-art trackers from the literature.

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency-matched-string: Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council
xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency: Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Manuscript received October 9, 2015; revised December 28, 2015; accepted January 1, 2016. Date of publication January 5, 2016; date of current version February 24, 2016. This work was supported in part by the European Union through the Program Robotic Manipulation for Nuclear Sort and Segregation under Grant H2020 and Grant 645582, in part by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council under Grant EP/M026477/1, and in part by the National Science Foundation, China, under Grant 61171136. The associate editor coordinating the review of this paper and approving it for publication was Prof. Jun Ohta.

abstract.ce:para: This paper presents a new method for object tracking in a camera sensor with particle filters. The method enables multiple target and background models, arbitrarily spanning many features or imaging modalities, to be adaptively fused to provide optimal discriminating ability against changing backgrounds, which may present varying degrees of clutter and camouflage for different kinds of features at different times. Furthermore, we show how to continuously and robustly relearn all models for all feature modalities online during tracking and for targets whose appearance may be continually changing. Both the data fusion weightings and model relearning parameters are robustly adapted at each frame, by extracting contextual information to inform the saliency assessments of each part of each model. In addition, we propose a two-step estimation method for improving robustness, by preventing excessive drifting of particles during tracking past challenging, cluttered background scenes. We demonstrate the method by implementing a version of the tracker, which combines both shape and color models, and testing it on a publicly available benchmark data set. Results suggest that the proposed method outperforms a number of wellknown state-of-the-art trackers from the literature.
